title: Pictured: Boy, 9, who 'murdered 3 toddlers and two adults in mobile home fire'
text:
Kyle Alwood, 9, has been identified by his mother for the first time, two days after he was charged with murdering five people including half-sister Rose, top right, and half-brother Daemeon, bottom right (Pictures: CBS News/Legacy.com)

A nine year-old boy accused of murdering three toddlers and two adults in a house fire has been named and pictured for the first time.

Kyle Alwood was identified by his mother Katrina Alwood during an interview with CBS This Morning on Thursday, with the stricken mom saying she forgives her son for his alleged crimes.

Katrina, who spoke two days after first-degree murder charges were announced over the April inferno, said: ‘Everyone is looking at him like he’s some kind of monster, but that’s not who he is.

‘People make mistakes, and that’s what this is.

‘Yes, it was a horrible tragedy, but it’s still not something to throw his life away over.’

Kyle’s mother Katrina Alwood appeared on TV Thursday to say that she still loves her son, and forgives him for his alleged crimes (Picture: CBS News)

A nine year-old boy has been charged with murder after allegedly starting a fire that killed (L-R) Rose Alwood, Dameon Wall and Dameon’s sister Ariel Wall (Pictures: Legacy.com)

Alwood, 27, said her son had been diagnosed with schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and ADHD, and that he’d previously expressed an interest in lighters and fire.

Kyle is accused of starting a blaze at a mobile home in Goodfield, Indiana, in April that killed his two half-siblings – Ariel, one, and two year-old Daemeon Wall.

The blaze also killed his two year-old cousin Rose Alwood, Kyle’s stepdad Jason Wall, 34, and his maternal great grandma, Kathryn Murray, 69.

Alwood, who was mother to Ariel and Daemeon, said she stood by the window of the burning home and sobbed on realizing that she couldn’t save them.

She said: ‘Mommy was right here and I loved them.

Also killed in the fire was Daemeon and Ariel’s great-grandma Kathryn Murray, 69, and her grandson Jason Wall (Pictures: Legacy.com)

‘You know, so, at least hopefully they heard that. I told Jason I loved him… And then something told me that they’re gone.’

Alwood says she heard Jason Wall – her fiance – scream as the blaze took hold. All five victims died of smoke inhalation.

And she insisted she will always support her alleged killer son, saying: ‘I forgive him. I love him no matter what.’

Katrina’s sister Samantha Alwood – Rose’s mom – has taken a harder line on her nephew, and says he should be sent to a juvenile detention center, then prison.

She explained: ‘Because at the end of the day, whether he meant to or not, he knew what fire did.’

All five were killed in this April 2019 blaze at a mobile home in Goodfield, Illinois (Picture: Shawn Johnson)

Despite his aunt’s wish, Kyle Alwood has not been placed in custody, because of his age.

He is instead being kept in an undisclosed location because of death threats made against him.

His trial will be heard by a panel of judges, rather than a jury.

If convicted, he will not be sent to prison, and will be sentenced to at least five years probation, which will end before he reaches the age of 21.

The youngster is next due to appear before a court on October 21.
description: Kyle Alwood's mother Katrina says her son suffered from various mental illnesses and that she forgives him for the blaze that killed two of her other children
